bestBHT.bht: The denarius, a Roman soldier's daily pay and liberal amount for a day's work, serves as a representation of God's generosity and grace. The parable emphasizes the abundance and blessings that God freely bestows upon those who enter into his service. Additionally, it highlights the distinction between those called to serve God from an early age and those called later in life. Ultimately, the parable conveys that salvation is a free gift from God, granted generously to all who respond to his call.

Henry Alford: The denarius a day was the pay of a Roman soldier in Tiberius’ time, a few years before this parable was uttered.

Polybius (but in illustrating the exceeding fertility and cheapness of the country) mentions that the charge for a day’s entertainment in the inns in Cisalpine Gaul was half an as, = 1/20th of the denarius.
This we may therefore regard as liberal pay for the day’s work.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 2. And when he had agreed with the
labourers for a penny—a usual day's hire.
Albert Barnes: The coin here referred to was a Roman coin, equal in value, at different periods, to 15 cents or 17 cents (7 1/2 d. to 8 1/2 d.) (circa 1880’s).
The original denotes the Roman denarius δηνάριον dēnarion, a silver coin, which was originally equivalent to ten ases (a brass Roman coin), from which it gets its name.
It was probably at that time the price of a day’s labor. See Tobit 5:14. This was the common wages of a Roman soldier.
Marvin Vincent: A denarius, the chief silver coin of the Romans at this time, and of the value of about seventeen cents.
A denarius was regarded as good pay for a day's work.
In almost every case where the word occurs in the New Testament it is connected with the idea of a liberal or large amount.
Philip Schaff: Inconsistent with the dignity of the parable; and inapplicable to the Apostles.
Eternal salvation is meant; for while the idea of reward is present, the whole drift of the parable teaches us that God’s grace is free.
Those first called represent nationally the Jews, called with a definite covenant; individually, those called in early life and who have spent their days in God’s service.
Archibald T. Robertson: For a penny a day (εκ δηναριου την ημεραν). See on Matthew 18:28. "Penny" is not adequate, "shilling" Moffatt has it."
The εκ with the ablative represents the agreement (συνφωνησας) with the workmen (εργατων).
"The day" the Greek has it, an accusative of extent of time.
John Gill: he that is hired for a day may demand it all the night; and he that is hired for a night may demand it all the day
And the wages of a day were usually a penny
By the penny a day agreed for with the labourers, may be meant external privileges; or the free promise made... of a sufficient supply of grace daily
John Wesley: The Roman penny was about seven pence halfpenny. [About thirteen and three quarter cents, American.] This was then the usual price of a day's labour.

bhtAttempts.bht: The parable can be understood as a demonstration of the generosity and grace of God. The denarius, the agreed upon payment for a day's work, was a significant and generous amount at that time. It symbolizes the abundant provision and blessings that God freely bestows upon those who enter into his service. The parable also highlights the distinction between those who have been called to serve God from an early age and those who have been called later in life. Ultimately, the parable reminds us that salvation is a gift from God, granted freely and graciously to all who respond to his call.

The denarius, a Roman soldier's daily pay and liberal amount for a day's work, serves as a representation of God's generosity and grace. The parable emphasizes the abundance and blessings that God freely bestows upon those who enter into his service. Additionally, it highlights the distinction between those called to serve God from an early age and those called later in life. Ultimately, the parable conveys that salvation is a free gift from God, granted generously to all who respond to his call.

The agreement of the laborers to work for a denarius, a Roman soldier's wage, demonstrates the generous pay for a day's work. The denarius is considered good pay and is connected with the idea of a liberal or large amount. It symbolizes the abundant provision and blessings that God freely grants to those who enter into his service. The parable also highlights the distinction between those called to serve God from an early age and those called later in life. Ultimately, it reminds us that salvation is a gift from God, granted freely and graciously to all who respond to his call.

The denarius, a generous payment for a day's work, signifies God's abundant grace and provision. The parable emphasizes that salvation is a free gift from God, bestowed generously to all who respond to His call. It illustrates the distinction between those who have been called early in life and those who have responded later. Ultimately, the story communicates the message of God's graciousness and highlights the boundless blessings that come from serving Him faithfully.

The denarius, equal to a Roman soldier's wage and regarded as good pay, symbolizes the liberal amount that God bestows upon those who serve Him. This parable underscores the idea that salvation is a free gift of God's grace. It portrays the differentiation between those who are called to serve God from a young age and those who respond later in life. Ultimately, the parable highlights the abundant blessings that come from faithfully serving God and emphasizes the generosity of His grace.
